docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I am all too aware of the litigious nature of our society, which nothing short of an overhaul of our legal system will change. But by controlling patients' access to care, health maintenance organizations are practicing medicine, and they must be accountable for their decisions. Rather than hurt the H.M.O. industry, the patients' rights bill passed by the House (front page, Oct. 8) will probably help it.
docs.abstract: Dr Jay S Markowitz letter on Oct 8 article sees patients' right bill approved by House helping health maintenance organization industry by spurring enrollment of healthy patients in managed care

docs.lead_paragraph: Ilene Ruth Penn and Dr. Craig Alan Miller are to be married this evening by Rabbi Richard A. Davis at Bridgewaters, a caterer in New York. The bride, 30, is the executive director of the Cure for Lymphoma Foundation in New York. She graduated magna cum laude from Boston University and received a law degree from Catholic University and a Master of Laws degree in advocacy from Georgetown University.

docs.lead_paragraph: Johanna Claire Goodman and Rodger Henry Stevens, who are artists, were married on Friday in a civil ceremony at the Municipal Building in Manhattan. The bride, 30, is a freelance illustrator in Manhattan. The bridegroom, 32, is a sculptor in Manhattan whose work was shown last year at the Katonah (N.Y.) Museum of Art.

docs.lead_paragraph: ENSCONCED near the Teton Range to the northwest and the Gros Ventre Range to the northeast, Jackson Hole remains relatively isolated, and its 6,500 year-round residents take brawny pride in their rugged Shangri-La. For hunters, fishermen, rafters, skiers and hikers, this piece of Wyoming is indeed a paradise. And in recent years, a lively restaurant scene has joined the list of enticements. The town of Jackson, which you can traverse on foot in 15 minutes, is not the rough-and-tumble mountain outpost I had expected -- unless you consider Eddie Bauer and Orvis the equivalents of Wild West general stores. Restaurants are insouciantly casual (I think I possessed the only tie in town), and urban Lewis and Clarks will find food and wine reasonably priced.

headline.main: In Jackson Hole, the Grazing Takes a Sophisticated Turn

docs.abstract: Bryan Miller reviews restaurants in Jackson Hole, Wyoming: Grill at Amangani, Snake River Grill, Restaurant Terroir, Sweetwater Restaurant, The Range, The Pines and The Bunnery; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: John Birks (Dizzy) Gillespie, the trumpeter, lived in Englewood from 1964 until his death in 1993. He lent his name to the Dizzy Gillespie Foundation, an organization at Englewood Hospital that provides free medical services to uninsured professional jazz musicians. Dr. Francis Forte, Gillespie's oncologist and a founding member of the foundation, is passionate about the need to offer services to musicians who receive little recognition or pay. Dr. Forte, who is also a jazz guitarist, spoke at his Englewood office about the history and importance of the foundation.

headline.main: A Medical Haven for Indigent Jazz Musicians

docs.abstract: Dr Francis Forte, oncologist and founding member of Dizzy Gillespie Foundation at Englewood Hospital in New Jersey, answers questions on foundation, which provides free medical services to uninsured professional jazz musicians; photo (On the Map column) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Nassau County's Department of Social Services announced in April that it would no longer provide many substance abusers with transportation to treatment centers, Halina Schafer felt ''a sense of terror'' among the drug-addicted women in the intensive five-day-a-week treatment program she runs in Freeport. Half a year later, Ms. Schafer said, six of the nine women who relied on the free van service are using drugs again. Ms. Schafer, director of Mercy Women's Day Rehabilitation Services, a program run under the auspices of Mercy Medical Center in Rockville Centre, called the county cutback ''a precipitating factor'' in the quick relapse of one young woman who later bore a crack-addicted baby.

headline.main: Cuts Open Gaps in Social Services Net

docs.abstract: Article on widening gaps in social service program offerings in Nassau County, Long Island, as result of cuts in county funding; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE signs are unmistakable: Washington is rediscovering the health care crisis. It did not, after all, go away with the failure of the Clinton Administration's attempt at universal coverage in 1994. New Census data show the number of uninsured Americans is climbing, in the face of an extraordinary economic boom. The cost of health insurance, after a few years of stability, is rising as well. The House of Representatives spent last week in angry, anguished debate over the state of the nation's health care, then passed a sweeping new bill to rein in the managed care industry and protect patients' rights. And out on the Presidential campaign trail, candidates are beginning to offer their solutions -- with much political forethought -- to the increasingly apparent problems of access, cost and coverage.

headline.main: The Nation: Rx Redux; Fevered Issue, Second Opinion

docs.lead_paragraph: FROM his judicial offices here, Andrew P. O'Rourke, the former Westchester County Executive, lives a professional life out of the public limelight that he once embraced. Now as a judge -- Judge O'Rourke of the Court of Claims -- he has realized what he always considered to be the pinnacle of a career as a lawyer.

headline.main: O'Rourke Reflects On Life as Judge, Not Politician

docs.abstract: Interview with former Westchester County Executive Andrew P O'Rourke, 65, who comments on his new post as Court of Claims judge, which allows him more time to write novels, latest of which is Life Is Good; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: MIKE LYNCH would probably have stumped the panel on the old ''What's My Line.'' His twinkly blue eyes, impishly salty language and well-cut suits would point to hard-driving real estate type, maybe, or brash young entrepreneur. Actually, Michael W. Lynch has been both those things. But at 39, what he is -- incongruously to many, but logically in his mind -- is a metals man who loves playing David to corporate Goliaths.
docs.abstract: Profile of Michigan Avenue Partners executive Mike Lynch, 39, whose subsidiary, McCook Metals, has offered to top bid by Alcoa Inc to buy Reynolds Metals; photo (M)
